newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu seeks way out of political trouble.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu seeks way out of political trouble.

text.p: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will try to end a political quarrel which has shaken Israel's government by holding talks with Foreign Minister David Levy on Wednesday.

The prime minister's office said the two men would meet at 12:30 p.m. (0930 GMT). It will be their first confrontation since the disgruntled foreign minister threatened on Monday to quit over the way the government was run.
Levy, a political veteran, accused Netanyahu of keeping him in the dark on important issues including political appointments and Middle East peace moves.

Analysts predicted the government would survive the crisis, which underscored growing disenchantment with the prime minister and with a three-and-a-half-month-old impasse in peacemaking because of Jewish settlement construction.

Netanyahu, clearly hoping to placate Levy, told reporters on Tuesday: "I believe the most natural thing from my standpoint is that the foreign minister guide the daily work between us and the Palestinians. I believe a way will be found also to implement this."
Levy's threat to resign was triggered by a media disclosure last week that National Infrastructure Minister Ariel Sharon secretly met top Palestinian official Mahmoud Abbas.
Levy said he would have supported the meeting but complained that he had not been informed about it.
Sharon ruled out a meeting with Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on the heels of his talks with Abbas, the Palestinian negotiatior of the 1993 peace accord with Israel.
"I always said I am willing to meet Palestinians. With Arafat I was not willing to meet, I am not willing to meet and I will not be willing to meet," Sharon told Israel Radio.

Levy has said his Gesher faction, with five of the 66 coalition seats in the 120-member parliament, is disappointed by Netanyahu's failure to advance peace moves or to improve life for low-income Israelis.
If Levy took Gesher out of the government, Netanyahu's fate would depend on an unstable parliamentary majority of one built on rebellious Likud members who are also threatening to bolt.
Two ministers have already left the cabinet. Netanyahu had hoped to get parliamentary approval on Monday for Sharon to replace one of them, Dan Meridor, as finance minister.
